reviews.content: Only reason it was made! I'm sure Keanu was probably paid in Blue Diamonds for this movie.

The tension never stopped. Gloriously, there were no car chases, no kids, no dog/cat worship, no political correctness. Molly Ringwald was a non-entity.
Some violence, but little gratuitous.

reviews.review_title: A world with no exit, indeed.
reviews.content:
I guess most reviews are negative because the movie was advertised as a 'Keanu Reeves thriller' so they expected an action thriller. But John Wick this is not, and I'm really glad it isn't. This is a slow paced, very old school, psychological thriller. The air is thick with danger, the menaces are everywhere, the main character navigates dangerous waters, but there is no 'action' scene per se until the ending. The film follows its path, slowly but surely towards the inevitable. 
The script is basic and rather clicheistic, but saved by strong, nuanced performances. 
To quote two interviews, this is a grown-up movie about people and relationships. A bit of redemption, too.

Watched this solely because I thought I'd see Keanu kick some a$$ but it never really happened. More of a romance movie.. Lots of Sex. Ashley st. George is a babe. Hope to see her in more movies. She kept my interest, but that's about it.
The movie was actually good. Great plot and so many bad things happened that you were sure it would end great. The ending made me change from an 8 to a 6. It just sucked!

Buying a ticket for a Keanu Reeves movie is like buying a Pot Noodle, you don't quite know what's motivating you, you know you'll be bitterly disappointed, and you swear minutes in that you'll never be so stupid again. But once every couple of years you do it - as if to commemorate that life could be so much worse.KR could not be more wooden if he came packaged two by four. His ageing face contains no wrinkles, they are merely knots and growth rings. I've read that he is a charming man. Fine. Just don't act. Play to your strengths - whatever they may be.Siberia is dreadful. You'd be better off eating dehydrated food from a Pot.

reviews.review_title: Unfulfilled promises from an otherwise nice suspense plot
reviews.content:
Siberia is the story of Lucas Hill (Reeves) an american diamond trader who is left by himself to negotiate with a russian mobster by his fleeting (diamonds and all) russian partner Pyotr. 
The plot takes Hill to a ever-rising dangerous situation making you guess what would the ace up his sleeve be that could give him and his lover Katya (Ularu) safe-passage out of the mess and into a happy ending. 
That´s to say, nearly a hundred minutes of intriguing plot, superb acting, interesting characters, cool locations, etc., all contributing to building up a climax that ends up being as blunt and surprising, as unsatisfaying. 
It´s not that you expected a ´John Wick´-ish solution to the tangle, but... really? Just... that?? You end up feeling lied to.

Fresh on Netflix I completely forgot this existed after it released in the back end of last year though to be completely honest I'm not convinced the cinematic release ever happened but regardless it fell by the wayside completely during the decent year in film of 2018. Anyway onto this, I saw it yesterday and I'd struggle to recall any story points if my life depended on it, which is not a good sign. There's a diamond mix up, Keanu Reeves who I'm pretty sure is nameless other than 'American' has an affair after his wife ends a Skype call, he breaks his image as John Wick and kills a dog and there's a conspiracy...I think. Now that took far too long to be worth the effort but all you need to know is there's nothing that happens, it does feel like a fill in story between Wick films that's supposed to build up the legend but fails completely. He's spends 90% of his time in Russia moving from hotel to hotel, changing his phone number and making the same call, then 'enjoying' (to say the least) his time with a random cafe worker called Katya who suddenly becomes his shadow and is in practically every scene. It culminates in Reeves finding his business partner dead and frozen and a gunfight where suddenly the clearly combat skilled American businessman offers himself to the villains essentially, standing in a clearing and getting shot in the head from behind before the credits roll. Thrilling! Utterly boring and very long sections plug the spaces between where he sits in on conversations that make jokes at him or where he stops a load of drunks making a mess but it's not worth an hour and 50 if your time, in the end being batched for me personally with the likes of 'Strangers: Prey at Night' and 'Rampage' amongst others in the truly appalling bottom end of the proverbial 2018 film ladder, skip this one

reviews.review_title: I disagree with most of the reviews here
reviews.content: I'm surprised by the bad ratings here. I thought the film was pretty good. The only bad acting is Keanu Reeves. So what else is new? Its dark and tragic and perhaps a little slow moving. He has a pretty steamy relationship with a Russian girl played by Ashley St. George. I thought that was all well done. Anyway, to me this film was a nice change of pace.

Wasteland. Sparsely populated. Knowing so few people and of those few, not many will be willing to help him. Arctic cold. Where one would be sent for the slightest of transgressions. A way station to somewhere. Into this world an American diamond merchant Lucas Hill is thrown-as Heinlein wrote a stranger in a strange land. Where he should have been aware of the old maxim "Business is business" and realizing too late he has been taken advantage of. Nihilism his only friend.
Ah if only... Siberia is none of those things. If only Siberia knew what it wanted to be. Neo noir? A straightforward drama masquerading as a crime thriller? A heist in the manner of Thief? It fails in the most fundamental way. It strives to be an existential drama without the underlying existentialism. Either Hamel/Scott and Ross didn't know how to convey this or were too lazy to give anything more than a slipshod effort.
If critics and users (here's looking at you Saban Films) were expecting John Wick Chapter 21, that's on you not Reeves who as Lucas Hill acquits himself rather nicely here.
Siberia could have been Body Heat meets Blood Diamond set against the shadow of current Russian political climate with a bit of Thief thrown in for good measure. 
Much has been made of sex scenes. I believe the intent was to initially show lustful convenience (what there are no other females around? She is the only woman at the bar/café he frequents). If there had of been, then his attraction to her would have been more palpable. From the first tryst at her urging to a gradual deepening of Lucas' love for her. The tone never changes from the first time he meets her to the last time he sees her. The latter should have evoked feelings of poignant tenderness in say the same way as Elba's/Winslet's did in The Mountain between Us. But fails to do so.
Although I knew the outcome 5 minutes into the film, (the film is constructed in such a way as to lend itself to what should be an unexpected ending) it should have resonated more than it did.
To appropriate Jim Morrison, Siberia is pretty good but it could have been far better than it is.
He kissed a girl who just suck another man thing, makes him look bisexual! Too much sex with no action! It should have been a porn!

reviews.review_title: Movie that takes itself seriously but it's just a joke ....
reviews.content:
Really disappointed by this movie, I wanted to see it and well I would not have
it is a film without soul, there are no characters, the only "living" is Lucas (Keanu Reeves) alone is caught in a drama and his suffering is real.
Katya (Ana Ulary) I did not know her, I do not know if she did any other movies before, but she's a bad comedienne, she does not feel any feelings (she's pretty, though) but that's not the case not enough. In this Siberia, it is cold, very cold ... is like extreme cold it numbs us until we totally darken. This is not a love film, lol I read the opposite on a criticism, I said to myself Ana you do not have a heart! lol but actually the person who put 10/10 is a fan of Keanu lol so this explains that. I also like Keanu but despite his performance the film is bad, it is badly put together, when we are promised a direction finally it changes and in the end nothing has been accomplished. I'm disappointed, I do not know what the director wanted to do, but it's bad, maybe he himself did not know ... except the sex, what a pain to have to undergo so much sex scene in a story none. In general too much sex shows a great weakness in a scenario, this is also the case. One question, Why Keanu Reeves is he going to do this movie? ;)) I just said, "It's a very big actor because living the feelings alone is very strong that" .... at the same time it is very strong, it's still John Wick (and of course, many other very beautiful films to his credit) he lost himself in the siberia that between us is very poorly filmed too ... not had the feeling of being in Siberia. Siberia has the tone and look of a live-to-video feature.
The various twists are useless, nothing sincere, nothing profound, everything is said very quickly and there will be no real evolution. By that I mean that nothing will come to surprise you, there are very long scenes ... long ... it is a difficult path for the spectator.

reviews.review_title: Not only Keanu Reaves is present.
reviews.content:
Many underlined the vacuity of the plot.
I disagree. It requires an difficult decision to kill Keanu. Other actors have given much and someone has thought about behaving like real Russian people...not in a bad way, I mean. About a nubilous business, with so many real cases of deathly consequences. You got it. 
If I went through to the grieving end, although in two parts, it is a solid, although improvable work.

What a good film this was. Honestly, Reeves has really gotten some great material over the last few years and has made the most of it. Superb story with fantastic production, acting and writing...could have used a bit more in the action department, but maybe I got spoiled with the Wick offerings. Definitely worth the price of admission...

I read a lot of bad reviews but I put my trust in Keanu. Some will look at a tapestry and see a square made of yarn and some will notice the rich details and complex patterns. This this is a movie that is loaded with interesting and intricate story points.. all through the beginning, middle, and end. It will not please everyone, no doubt, for reasons that will become obvious after watching but Siberia is well worth the journey.

Lucas Hill (Reeves) goes to Siberia to make a diamond deal, but his partner Pyotr (Boris Gulyarin) has left the meeting place apparently with the diamonds. Lucas promises Boris Volkov (Pasha D. Lychnikoff) a sample with the remaining 11 to come later. And yes, this is love story too. Okay, while we wait for John Wick 3 to come about, we have Keanu Reeves in a role we don't normally see him in. He falls in love with a pretty Katya (Ana Ularu) and we are not sure why (We can see why) as we think his marriage to his wife (Molly Ringwald) seems to be okay. But, of course, we don't know anything more about that. And we only see Molly Ringwald for about 20-seconds in the beginning. When Lucas meets with Boris to give him the one good sample he has, Boris makes a very unusual sexual proposal now that Katya is also there as she followed Lucas to that meet. Boris wants Lucas to allow Katya to orally service him and Lucas will be orally serviced by Boris' girlfriend. Boris says this is all in the context of Brotherhood between he and Lucas. These are very uncomfortable scenes. Later on the Russian FSB (former KGB) gets involved and Lucas has a decision to make or not make to save Katya's life.Notables: Rafael Petardi as Paval, who protects Boris' interests; James Grace as Vincent, who warns Lucas the FSB is looking into him regarding the diamond transactions. The acting all around is very good and I am sure we will see more of the very pretty and striking Ana Alaru (See? You did notice) (7/10)Violence: Yes.
Sex: Yes.
Nudity: Yes.
Humor: No.
Language: Yes.
Rating: B

reviews.review_title: John Wick on a depressing and dull Siberian vacation.
reviews.content: The trailer made this actually look like a cheap Wick spinoff with enough action and thrills for a VOD film to keep Your attention.Every actual action shot in the trailer is really only 2 separate :30 total sequences in the beginning and in the end of this film. Instead it's Keanu in a more reserved and boring Wick persona venturing around a bleak Siberian environment of rich Russian mobsters and a very annoying sex crazed Russian woman that is unconvincing. The plot drags around and really is cliche as they come with stolen diamonds and blown mobster kingpin deals with utterly banal dialogue. The ending comes abruptly with no real conclusion and the film is over. While Keanu delivers his signature acting style that's servacable for the most part, there's really no reason to watch this. It's essentially John Wick on a depressing vacation without any action or excitement Obsessed with a Russian chick.
A lot of sex with no sense, no sexy at all in a pooor story... Long time

Typical boring, Russian garbage. Netflix should remove all Russian made films from their site. They are rarely any good.I don't know why Reeves would sign on for such crap. I guess the money was too good to pass up.

reviews.review_title: Stop copying all the bad reviews
reviews.content: When I scroll through the reviews after watching the film, it seems like most of the reviewers are just copying each other. Most are saying, "worse film ever". Worse film ever?!! Seriously? Maybe you only ever saw a few films then...OK, so compared with John Wick, it is nowhere near as good, but it's not that kind of film. No, it's not really good, and is a little flat and isn't exciting. But, it does make a nice change. Things don't always work out for the better in life, people's lives are a mess and can be depressing. This film captures that. Another reviewer remarked that you knew it was going to end badly for someone. But for who? The ending is not "weird", "pointless" or "rubbish". The ending is actually kind of perfect. If you want exciting, ignore this film. If you want a film that is slow paced and more like reality in a place where things are done differently, watch it. I will say that the Russian gangster was the best casted and what I expect from someone like this - enjoyed their scenes.Give it a try, but don't expect John Wick.

reviews.review_title: Depressing waste of talent and some decent performances
reviews.content: Lazy writing and a poorly developed plot sink this Siberian morass. The acting is actually quite good throughout, but the story really makes no sense. You're never quite clear about the motivation of Reeves and so he kind of wanders through the story-detached and unemotional.I think the acting could almost be strong enough to salvage something of the film had there not been a total lack of a third act leaving Reeves dead on the ground and a very underwhelming cut to credits.One is left just sitting there. Hence the poor ratings. The writer was either unloved as a child or lazy.And don't for a minute believe this is some deep character study that underscores the modern decathected ennui between two lovers who find themselves going nowhere mid life. While that's a theme (or an attempt at one). The movie never really has the balls to get into some of that material. Rather it's skips over some rather tense moments and maintains a flaccid detachment. There no great film here or great Cinema. Only the fake blue diamonds.Either way save two hours of you life and read Solzhenitsyn instead. This film is dreadful.

reviews.review_title: I really hate a movie critic
reviews.content: Because my opinion is what matters to me. Siberia is a jewel of a movie. Very hot. Very moody. Pacing reminded me of Bound. Sexy like Bound too. Reeves looks great. Lot of chemistry with Ularu. Perfect movie to see at home if you can't catch it in a theater with the limited release. I got it on Demand for $7.99. Hoping for some extra features when the blu-ray comes out. Commentary with Reeves and Ularu would be very special. Just throwing it out to the universe...

The last minute.This film really doesn't seem to have a point. It's just about some people and a few somewhat interesting days of their lives. And then it ends poorly.Oh yeah, there's some sex, and Molly Ringwald has a speaking role, don't blink or you'll miss it. Reeves is a nice guy, and he's rich but lives a modest lifestyle, he probably did this movie as a favor to a friend.
The worste story ever... Keanu is good but there is no story here

reviews.review_title: I said it before and I'l say it again Keanu Reeves simply can't act.
reviews.content: I said it before and I'll say it again Keanu Reeves simply can't act. I've watched mostly all of Reeves film, from Bill & Ted, to the Matrix trilogy the Watcher, John Wick, that mega piece of s...t Knock Knock (what a total crapfest) and I can safely say that Keanu Reeves is no actor, he is a nice face for the camera with absolutely no depth nor dimension in any role he plays. He is bland thru and thru. Let's face it, the Matrix is what gave him star power, because of the fight scenes, like John Wick. Take away that and all you have is a lousy actor playing roles in awful movies like Siberia compensating by being in numerous sex scenes. This films confirms that Keanu suck major ass a lead, without any fight scenes. He is just lousy. Avoid this stupid ass film at all cost.

reviews.review_title: If you enjoy John Wick you'll enjoy this, solid 5.7
reviews.content: Don't understand these brain dead ratings but I don't understand the world in general anymore when cheesy super hero movies get 9s 10s.Going by the old IMDb ratings from 10 years ago this is a solid 5.7 - 6. To have this in the 4s in the same category as Horrendous B movies is insane.There need not be a deep story to enjoy this movie. It's a slow burner with a very superficial story, but it's still very enjoyable. It's John Wick with less killing, if you want suspense it's definitely there.I enjoyed all the John Wick movies even though they weren't masterpiece but legit Solid 6s. If you enjoy those give this movie a try, the acting is very good. Ignore the horrendous ratings and enjoy a Russian nostalgic noir.

reviews.review_title: A slow-burning senseless moody B movie with no mood
reviews.content: Keanu Reeves as slightly dodgy diamond merchant Lucas Hill whose Russian partner goes missing, travels to St. Petersburg to find him, but instead he falls into an obsessive and passionate relationship with a local cafe owner (Ana Ularu) in Siberia. Movie has a dark tone in its cinematography and music, but it fails to reflect that quality in its story because it raises certain expectations, but it fails to live up to them as the film ends unexpectedly, thus, killing the excitement. The film's screenplay, also, fails to connect the dots on how Reeves has ended up in the situation he's in. At the end, movie works neither as an action film, nor as a romantic story, nor as a crime thriller. In trying to do too much, it falls between the cracks of each genre. Without characters interesting enough to hold attention, nor a story exciting enough to do the same, there is little to recommend in this film that lacks a final punch.5/10
I cannot believe you have accepted this movie. Please don't watch it. The story line is so awful, if there is one.

reviews.review_title: Low key love story with hints of violence
reviews.content: Siberia is a love story and a vehicle for the two leads. They were well cast, both are good looking and have good lines to say, and are featured making love maybe four times. That part of the movie works well, and is romantic and filmed really well. Siberia is not an action movie, although all the players are there to make it one. It's charm is realism, and this depiction is probably much closer to how an innocent, but ultimately bad deal with criminals, actually pans out. On that score it certainly has interesting tension, and one will certainly feel for the dilemmas that face Mr Reaves. A stranger in a strange land indeed, and that is probably what the movie makers had in mind when they titled this Siberia (a lot of the footage is St Petersburg). How successful they were on this score is reflected in my score for the movie.

reviews.review_title: icy, flat, just blows the surface
reviews.content:
Lucas Hill (Keanu Reeves) negotiates the sale of diamonds to the Russian oligarch Boris Volkov (Pasha D. Lychnikoff). Among the threats, the risks and with other buyers trying to interfere with the transaction, Hill eventually gets involved with Katya (Ana Ularu), owner of a local bar.It is unfortunate to note the wasted potential: Russia offers many opportunities for opening up to explore crime, drama and suspense. However, the conduct of this film ends up leaving the story slow, unsurprisingly. The existing romance is actually an excuse for inserting multiple sex scenes, which add absolutely nothing to the characters, who in turn are empty, with no specific goals.
Ross' glacial pacing does not help matters; Apart from not knowing how to evolve in both genres, Siberia has a disability based on an unfavorable scenario and where many moments are confused. One does not understand that the sexual attraction of the two protagonists in which the lack of chemistry is too visible provoking to leave the film several times. Chaos seizes a relationship that there is no where to take it.
The thriller plot works best despite some scenes that claim to be taken from a movie by Tarantino or Guy Richie and this is not always the most appropriate because of the tone in which Siberia is treated. Cold and soulless characters like these natural scenes that are not always exceptional and show the hardness and coldness of the region.
Predictably throughout Siberia perhaps because of the fusion of tones on the sex becomes confused and very flat.

Waste of time this movie
Only first 5 minutes were promising, but it spiraled out.
Deserves 0 stars.

reviews.review_title: Has its moments but fails under expectations
reviews.content: Probably the biggest mistake of the filmmaker in this case is to let Keanu carry his styling from John Wick into this movie. John Wick is so iconic now that if we have a protagonist who dresses like him, walks like him and talks like him, yet doesn't shoot like him; it will disappoint the audience. Well probably the movie was shot alongside John Wick 2 and Keanu might have put this condition on the filmmaker who had to play along.... Anyway, just watch it knowing that this is not a John Wick spin-off.Siberia is a retelling of the classic tale of a shady businessman/smuggler with not so friendly clientèle. Its every bit reminiscent of 'Lord of War' and 'Blood Diamond' but is neither exciting nor as thought provoking. Only thing which absolves this movie from being a total drag is the attention to the mundane aspects of a smuggler's life. There is something so uncouth and disdainful about the protagonist and his lack of innocence is disturbing. Is this the intended effect of Siberia? Perhaps!

Seen yesterday for my misfortune;) I do not recommend, I love Keanu Reeves is other film than John Wick, talented comedian with great charisma but he got lost in a movie rambling. It's a shame because he is very disturbing but he is the only one ... I was bored stiff, Ross had made a first film that without being excellent promised, the second is totally missed, not convaiquant ... The gangster ' have laughed, so far from the truth ... Matthew Ross has nothing depth he stays on the surface and goes in all directions, in the end is this a love movie? No, sex? No, because despite the sex scenes too generous for my taste :) it's very cold and without conviction, no echo is between Lucas and Katya.
The character Lucas is completely lost, and so are we. It happens to search Pyotr, the time is counted for Lucas and apparently in this film the notion of time does not exist. Lucas goes for a walk, he trails ... he trails ... He has time to meet and have a good time ... at Matthew Ross sex is scouring.
 Neither good Thiller, nor good romantic movie, nor drama ... the film dissolves readily and is completely tasteless.
1 star for Keanu Reeves only feels he concerned.

This is a movie about diamond smuggling and Keanu is a diamond appraiser and a go between. It mostly involves the Russian Mafia and a small interaction with the FSB (KGB) and the married Keanu meets a Russian girl while he travels between Russian cities and waits for his supplier & contacts.The movie is painfully slow and boring as he waits around from his AWOL contact for the diamonds. The action consists of his getting beat up and left in the cold to freeze. Heckled by the girls brothers because she took him home and they thought the worst. Sex every 5 minutes because she wants to get back at her brothers who thought the worst. They don't show any body parts. Just kinky behavior or places. And then the FSB gets into the picture and Keanu gets blackmailed and caught between them and the gangsters. The ending was really rotten' especially after suffering through a horribly slow, boring movie.The actors did their best despite a horrible script and worse directing because the director also approved the script and then made it worse. The script writer and director should limit their careers to the porn industry since that seems to be their only interest. I doubt any respectable film would hire them after this. I feel sorry for Keanu but I don't know whether this porn theme was to his taste or not. Pardon the pun.First: Film Makers need to understand that people who like a steady diet of porn or sex will be buying their movies from a porn store. Not watching movies. The focus of this movie does not appeal to anyone who would watch it. Nor would the 5 or 6 acts of sex (every 5 minutes) appeal to the porn addicts without showing any body parts but do their best to imply kinky acts and places. Porn lovers aren't interested in a story line, only sex, so why pursue this type of story line which offends both the regular audience and the porn lovers at the same time. So nobody likes it and they get nothing but bad reviews from being totally out of touch with their target audience.Second: Keanu looks terrible in a beard. I realize the actors who are straight wear beards in Hollywood so they wont get hit on as much but it looks terrible and ratty and adds 15 to 20 years to their age.Third: It was so painfully slow and boring as we watched Keanu fly back and forth between Russian cities and sit waiting at each place while the background actors have to carry the film until they give Keanu something to do, since that is how the script was written and not his fault. Then they add a Russian girl to the formula whose behavior doesn't warm her to the audience. This is the fault of the script writer and director. Not her. Then they have Keanu who allows her to be disrespected on the utmost of unforgivable levels... at which point he loses the respect of the audience... which was already hanging by a thread due to the issue of cheating on the wife.Fourth: This is truly a horrible job of script writing. The story theme was thin, Cagney corny, a subject of diamond smugglers right out of the 1940's which is of no interest to the audiences and a pitiful lack of action and plot. Plus the really rotten ending. There was less than 2 minutes of Keanu showing us his trade (out of bed). The film makers & scriptwriters need to learn to create movies that the audience likes. Not what they like. But as far as the script goes, there is no dialogue, no story beyond the diamond transaction and the Russian girl to fill the time. There is no reason Keanu should be wasting his talent on movies like this. He should get a better agent and find better movies before he loses his appeal. He also needs to shave the beard and mustache. It is quite awful and would be hard to get a decent acting job with it. Maybe another Sci-Fi film and a better writer and director.Fifth: However, the audience would have liked to have seen a movie actually made in Russia with a story about the interactions of the citizens, the gov't, the authorities and how they live and function on a personal level and the misbehavior of our CIA and Corporations taking advantage of them. And the aftereffects of their changing gov't and lifestyles... without the sex and only a brief reference to the mafia. We don't need to see another boring shootemup story again. Nor an FSB torture nor a focus on politics. It needs to be a character driven story with a character like Dobrynin with his humorous remarks to JFK and Haig.Dr Zhivago was a big hit so there is an audience for it. Telefon was also a good movie to watch as was the film SALT. Perhaps with a touch of humor like the Get Smart film and Yellow cake (Uranium).However I cannot recommend this movie to anyone. Not even for Keanu's sake. It is the movie and the script problems. Not his acting. Actors have to follow the script and the direction they are given. Clearly Keanu has a bad agent which he needs to change ASAP and stay away from sex oriented movies and gangster films.

reviews.review_title: One of the most confusing screenplays I have ever seen
reviews.content: This is my attempt of summarizing the characters in Siberia.It starts with Keanu wanting to see Pyotr. We never actually see Pyotr, but we get around eight scenes of Keanu getting/making a phone call, where he expresses his urgency in seeing Pyotr. Then we get introduced to Boris, who sells diamonds as well. He is the only character in the diamond industry we see, along with Vincent. Vincent and Keanu, allying with other South Africans apparently, once teamed up against Lagos. This explains their friendship, I guess. Andrei also sells diamonds, but we don't see him. Samsonov is also involved in the diamond industry, and as expected, we don't see him either. All we know about him is he is "a bad man." Volkov also participates in the diamond industry. A guy named Polozin has leverage over Keanu, and luckily we see him in a couple scenes.That's just the characters for the diamond industry. There are a whole lot of friends and family members from Keanu's multiple love interests.If that sounded confusing, that's because it is. This movie made no sense at all and I was confused within the first five minutes.

Big 0 !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
I'm angry, abducted from my life

The main problem the way I see it is that Keanu Reeves is presently eponymous with John Wick. As in fans, including myself literally see him (the onscreen version of him as John Wick) so its hard to see him not respond to situations the way John Wick would. The fact that John Wick 2 came out not long ago and John Wick 3 is in the works can't help but insert bias. I know I have it. So having said I know it affected how I saw the unfolding of the movie. I'd say that if say Ryan Gosling was playing the role I would give it a higher rating because he hasn't been a one-man army in recent years (wasn't really that in Drive either). For Keanu though this is just the fate that he is going to be having for a while. I mean it was hard enough not seeing him as Neo but I got past that albeit nearly 15-19 years later (if I include both movies).

I rented this movie on ondemand the first day it came out. Being a fan of anything that Keanu Reeves is in I was anxiously awaiting this movie as I knew it would be a different kind of movie for him. Mr. Reeves is a totally wonderful action star, but he is also a great actor when it comes to dark and psychological movies. This movie lived up to my expectations. This is a tragic love story between two people who are from different cultures and who have lives that they are trapped in. When they are thrown together because of a diamond deal gone awry, they develop a relationship that is both sensual, emotional and yes loving even though he is married and she is supposedly engaged. They become entangled in the Rissian mob about the diamond deal. Then things get dicey. The Russians don't play and they put these two people in a violent situation that they try to escape from. I thought the story was great. The characters were well played by Keanu and Una and their chemistry worked. They both exhibited great emotions through out the movie. Keanu's command of the Russian language was perfect. That in itself shows the work and passion he puts into every role he plays. All I can say is if your not interested in seeing a well thought out and acted movie for mature people who appreciate the noir type movie, then this movie is not for you. Of course there are a lot of CGI movies out there to hold your attention without you having to invest yourself in a thought provoking movie. I have already preordered my Blu-ray. Congratulations to all involved with this movie, a job well done.

Diamond smuggling in Siberia. I guess. anyway, we pretty much know where we're going here. but, Keanu always brings something to the table. if you're a fan, then go. enjoy. he's one of the producers, by the way.

reviews.review_title: The Cold Seeps Into The Performances
reviews.content: In dreary Siberia, diamond trader Keanu Reeves shows up to discover what has become of his missing partner. Instead of tending to business, he begins an affair with Ashley St. George, who doesn't like anyone. Others are interested in the big blue-white diamonds of questionable origin, as well as Miss St. George.Shot in a blue-grey haze to indicate just how cold the landscape and emotional content of the movie is, Keanu Reeves offers another of his blank-faced performances. He is certainly a serious actor, who works at his craft, but his range is of a peculiarly small variety, which makes him suitable for playing Bill, or someone who has half his brain carved out, but not someone with any emotional depth. He is a good-looking fellow who, like Robert Taylor before him, wishes to be a good actor, but who got a foothold because of his good looks, and keeps working because of it. The frigid story suits him, but does not hold my interest.

Same image, same haircut with same performance. I'm not say Reeves is a bad actor but why he didn't change something different for his each recent projects? the main point is, He's keeping his "very handsome" look since Generation Um (2012) so far. even John Wick series were his nowadays success that everyone claps their hands. But come to this movie , it seems like he took some new elegant pictures for Esquire or another entertainment magazines. Personally I think it's not quite excited at all.

reviews.review_title: Great movie; intriguing plot, articulated characters, exceptional acting, layers of suspense, romance and raunch, what's with all the 1 star spam?!
reviews.content: Keanu, top form, he must have practiced the Russian dialogue for weeks!As far as plot goes, blows John Wick 3 away (which really seemed to revolve around the action scenes and body count).The producers of Siberia did a wonderful job - wonderful juxtapositions of color and texture, for example, actors wearing blue and then in the next scene a literal 'fire orange', followed by an (artistic) clip of white snow melting off a dark roof. Then an action scene. Finesse!Didn't really like the ending of Siberia though, it kind of reduces the opportunity for a sequel?Certainly noticed some goofs, but still found it (well over a thousand times) more entertaining than that (critically acclaimed?!!) movie Nomadland - which was like watching wet cardboard dry over a bucket toilet.
It was ok, not Keanu Reeves greatest film. Not as bad as most reviewers make out it was though. Could have been better and have to say did not like the ending but overall middle of the road film.
This is Keanu Reeves' most boring and obnoxious movie by far. There is nothing it can make you feel, not even angry.

Short and sweet. 
The film reminds me of older works in the same genre. The intersections between characters, their flow, seem to mimic reality. Crime thrillers of recent vintage tend to be bloated, Siberia is far from that.
Ana Ularu and Keanu Reeves gel well together. Reeves still has that quality which makes you root for the main character, despite what transpires.
Siberia was a real gem I would recommend to everyone who likes Keany Reeves and are curious about Russian culture while enjoying great action scenes. It's a movie like we don't do anymore.

reviews.review_title: This movie made me cancel my Prime video membership

reviews.review_title: VIEWS ON FILM review of Siberia
reviews.content: Five production companies, one entertainment company, and one distributor had a hand in getting 2018's Siberia made. I'm no can-do Hollywood producer but I think it was worth it.Anyway, Siberia is a slow-burning and slow-churning thriller. It's similar yet antithetical to last year's The Snowman. Siberia's thrills nestle in the mind's eye and not in beatings, chases, or elaborate stunts. As something about a diamond merchant whose diamond selling deal goes sour and off the reservation, Siberia is like chic, Russian film noir with star Keanu Reeves playing a detective-free, Philip Marlowe type. Granted, Siberia could've improved on its standoff, shootout ending. It feels abrupt while portraying the Reeves persona as a protagonist afterthought (you see Keanu fending off bad dudes with a mag 10 and you salivate for more). Plus, side player Molly Ringwald who's an 80's actress icon, barely shows up in two faded scenes. Nonetheless, Siberia mostly draws you in and leaves your Basic Instinct-like psyche absorbed and content. Time to pour out a little cinematic liquor (in this case I'm talking vodka).Keanu Reeves as diamond trader Lucas Hill, sinks his teeth into a role that seems tailor made for him. Sans beating people up a la the styling of John Wick, Keanu relies on minimal talking, bleeding screen presence, and some gadgetry, physical hand movements. Keanu's Hill is in nearly every frame and you as the viewer, follow his every turn (and his many sexual trysts). Minus his work in Speed, Point Break, The Matrix, and Street Kings, this is probably my favorite performance from the guy whose name cordially means, "cool breeze over the mountains".Siberia's director is New York City native and Harvard graduate, Mathew Ross. His first flick titled Frank & Lola (which I have yet to see) supposedly is also of the racy, noir variety. With Siberia, Ross is manifest with his vision. He fills the screen with Siberian landscapes, various close-ups, soft-core sex scene realism, and cold, ominous background lighting. His calculated pacing along with Keanu's scruffy, roughed up stares into the camera, make Siberia work as crossfire fiction. In truth, this is not an action extravaganza or a headlong genre affair yet it sets you in motion. Would I recommend that you see Siberia with a refreshed open mind? As the Russians say, the answer would be a profound "da". Rating: 3 stars.

I will admit that the story is a little flat, but the acting, direction, and cinematography are very good. The latter three points strengthen the story, in spite of itself, but as a viewer, you can appreciate the work that was done.

reviews.review_title: Forcefully told yet contains subtlety in writing and acting
reviews.content: Reading the reviews here, the ambivalence among them piqued my interest, so I gave the film a watch. The majority of the reviews here do not match my experience. Accusations of bad writing do not correlate with the film I saw. Two cultures are juxtaposed, mainly from one culture's point of view, and though viewers may not like the result, thoughtful people cannot deny the truths presented. The film breaks certain writing taboos accepted in the commercial marketplace, and while containing both sex and violence, neither is gratuitous. The plot does not revolve around creating situations for maximum sensual thrills in the viewer, but in faithfully and carefully presenting a character-driven story. If you prefer not to watch this sort of movie, then I suggest you avoid this one. If you like films that successfully bridge genres between spy, thriller, and literary, then I suggest you give it a try. I thoroughly enjoyed it as one of the better new movies I have seen in a while and will remember scenes and story elements for some time to come.

reviews.review_title: Nothing is perfectly choreographed in real life combat
reviews.content: I suspect those who have rated this one star have never seen a movie more complex than "Transporter." This is not some John Wick movie ... nor is it intended to be. In fact, it is just the opposite. In this movie, just like in real life, no one is perfect.Lucas Hill, played by Keanu Reeves, is not some kind of superhero. He is just an ordinary man, caught in extraordinary circumstances. He makes mistakes. It happens. There is obvious chemistry between Reeves and co-star, the amazing Ana Ularu. This brings back memories of how great movies were once made. Every single character in this movie is perfectly crafted, and Katya, Pavel and Ivan are particularly outstanding.Beautifully shot, this is how movies were once made prior to the video-game/first-person shooter genre. The tension builds slowly, becomes palatable and finally explodes into a climax that neither tells you all the answers, or even explains all the questions.In real life, bear hunting in Russia has zero to do with sportsmanship. A bear is flushed from its den by dogs and surrounded by a circle of hunters who just open fire at it at near-contact distance. In the very real depiction of this in "Siberia," Ivan's dog is accidentally shot by one of the drunken hunters, and Ivan's hands are shaking so badly he can't even load another cartridge in his rifle to do the right thing to put it out of its misery. The realness of this touching scene has not been seen in a movie for many many years.This is only one example of how real the director has made this movie. In actual conflict, people get hurt ... even the good guys. Bullets go through wooden walls. People fumble. Things go wrong. Bravo to the filmmakers who have made a film that credits the audience with the intelligence to enjoy how gritty and real this is.The final scene shows almost everything that happens in real-life combat: tunnel vision; loss of fine motor skills; the good guys sometimes miss and the bad guys sometimes don't. In real life combat, nothing is perfectly choreographed, and the best plans immediately fall apart the moment the bullets start flying. In real life, sometimes a cornered bear still comes out of its den with a lot of fight, even when surrounded. I have seen this film three times so far in the past two days, and have seen more and more details every time. I actually feel sorry for people who want to rate this one star and who probably have never seen an intense drama with some amazing actors who are not just there to act in front of a green screen, gather a pay cheque and hope for big opening weekend numbers. This movie is a keeper.

I stumbled over this movie in the bargain bin at the store, and as a general fan of Keanu Reeves bought it. Before putting it into the player, my spouse read off a bunch of the reviews posted here, so we were prepared for the worst. It surely was not Bill and Ted's or Wick or Matrix - maybe, just maybe, an attempt at a slice of real life - at least for some. It was a drama and had a plot. It was sad. It was supposed to be sad. I think the movie did what it intended to do, and in that regard it was a successful movie, if not a fun one. The movie was successful enough that I went to the effort to make this review (my first in IMDB) to contrast the vehemence from so many others. Perhaps some reviewers took personal offense at seeing Russia and Russians portrayed as they were? It could have been set just about anywhere and the same human elements could still be found.

reviews.review_title: Excellently directed, superb acting for a Russian film that hits the mark.
reviews.content: I've read the reviews from others and I'd say they watched this expecting some kind of Hollywood film or John Wick type of thing. It's not full on action, and in fact the action and the diamond deals are really the background scenery to this film which is really about the affair the American has while he plunges himself into the Russian underground. There are many Russian films that move at a slow pace like this film and take a lot of time to set a scene and explore the characters. It's a Russian director, and he has applied his style to it well. It was funny in many respects, but clearly they focused on the narrative, for example, the locals were not kidding about his jacket. He would have died walking around Siberia like that. The number of locals that seem to effortlessly speak English, despite the explanation for Anna's capability, was just wrong. Having been to these areas, there is no one that speaks English in these remote Siberian towns. St Petersburg, of course, but not out in the bush of Siberia. Appropriate and very Russian ending as well.

reviews.review_title: Not essential. Film that has less interest.
reviews.content:
The film centers on the story of a diamond dealer Lucas Hill, who flies to Russia to run a trade in rare blue diamonds. The film explores (without success) Lucas's struggles to get out of a dubious situation when his contract is compromised.
Then he meets Katya (Ana Ularu) and from then on everything spoils, that I felt that the film began to wade. I felt that the romantic tension between the two characters wasn't at the rendez-vous. The chemistry between the actors isn't great, and the scenario is not really enough to develop the first steps of their relationship. I didn't appreciate Romance because of other flaws in character development.
When romance sets in, the film forgets its thriller side, it becomes a secondary plot and nothing is done to develop it. There are very tense moments, but these moments never come to nothing, because the diversions of the romantic story cool the tension.
At the beginning I was quite intrigued but over time, boredom and disinterestedness settled down, especially since the story of romance became much less interesting and rather simplistic, I mean that the characters don't are touched, that what you learn as you go hasn't the will to explain.
The performance of Keanu Reeves is correct in this film. Keanu Reeves is an excellent actor, and despite the fact that he doesn't know how to play Lucas Hill in the movie, Hill's room to grow. Because of this recurring scenario problem, Keanu Reeves doesn't have the usual presence.
Ana Ularu in her role is much further down, I have noted an incalculable number of fault, the experience is lacking. Pasha D. Lychnikoff is doing very well, but the screenplay is so far from reality and flat that it doesn't help.
It's a film that for the most part is confusing, Matthew Ross struggles to locate any sign of life. Management is less and Matthew Ross doesn't film anything strong, no soul in this movie. I can't consider this film as good, it has not fulfilled its contract, neither at the level of the entertainment and even less with regard to its depth. A movie that we can do without.

reviews.review_title: Boring, slow and a bad choice for Keanu Reeves
reviews.content: This film offers a story about diamond trafficking that could have worked well as either an action or a thriller, but in the end it is a rather dense film, with too much dramatic weight and lack of plots to fill in the holes, making it a confusing film, difficult to understand and even boring. Although the sexual tension of the leads could have been a good thing, the erotic scenes feel forced and unnecessary. Even the double oral sex scene can feel uncomfortable. As much as you pay attention, it is difficult to understand and you have to read the synopsis to understand what the hell is going on. The script is quite weak and lacks meaning and emotion and it doesn't even have a very good direction, since the film doesn't seem to know exactly where to go. The dialogues are poor and do not explain much. The concept of traffic and the Russian mafia is good, but it is very poorly planned and poorly developed. What is applaudable is the rawness that it has and how it tries to tell something real, but sadly it does not succeed. Something that can be appreciated is the participation of Keanu Reeves, which at least gives the film some life. Unfortunately, it's a bad movie whose only advantage is having a good actor in the lead. At least the final confrontation was something more or less acceptable, but with an unsatisfying ending. In conclusion, Siberia is one of the worst Keanu Reeves movies that had an interesting plot, but was poorly made, so it's not surprising that it has so many negative comments. My rating for this movie is 4/10.

So many gratuitous sex scenes, bordering on soft-porn. Gangsters who can't just make million dollar diamond deals without the seller being forced to have oral sex in front of them, so they can be "blood brothers". Too many groups of people (the South Africans, the Spetznas gang, Boris Volkov, Andrei and Pyotr and our hero, the girl's immediate family and friends--but no real exposition explaining anything).When he left the girl in the hotel to give Boris the single blue diamond, I thought that he was going to get busted, giving Boris the fakie, and his "girlfriend" taking the real diamond and scramming. That would have been good. But nooo...can't have actual suspenseful writing. Instead, his girlfriend inexplicably shows up at the meet, and is forced to perform oral sex on the gangster, or else! Of course she leaves what she thought was going to be a cocaine-and-booze party as if she'd been raped. Well...nobody told you to infiltrate a black-market million dollar diamond deal, dummy! And why would a gangster interested in diamonds FORCE his seller to do such disgusting things?Anyway, there was way too much time spent on the stupid sex and relationship with this Katya woman, who already had a beau, apparently (and our hero Lucas already married, too), as well as her vulgar family and friends (all male by the way). Very little explanatory dialog on what's happening--what did the S. Africans want? Why did the Russian police (FSB) force Lucas to sell the fake diamonds to Boris? What was the point of that? They didn't even show the cops busting him. Instead, they said "if you don't do this for us, Lucas, you know what will happen to the girl." What? I thought they were Russia's FBI? Instead, they act like gangsters.Then in the end we see the dead (but not frozen?) body of I guess is Pyotr, sitting in a chair, with bloody marks on his arms as if he died of hypothermia during a heroin overdose in some shack? If so, why wasn't he in his house? What was he doing in that little shack? How did Lucas find him? And why was Katya's brother so nice to him? And why did Lucas linger around, when he should have been on a plane outta there? And how did Boris's men find out the diamonds were fakes, if Boris himself told the spectrometer guy "we trust him. Put it away"? I guess they used it after his "blood brother" left?We never got to see the bad-ass Spetznas gang leader. And how did a fake diamond end up in a candle in the crappy Siberian motel? Pyotr left it there? Why? Did he expect Lucas to find it?The entire movie was a confusing stinker, and every 15 minutes it was sweaty, gritty soft-porn sex between big-toothed Katya and Lucas, and I disliked both of them: him, for cheating on his wife (explaining it as "squinting" at things? ) and her for falling so fast and hard for this inarticulate American diamond smuggler, when instead she had a good man (by all accounts), "Anton" to be with. No scene rang true or felt authentic. Terrible writing and screenplay. And Keanu's deadpan, boring delivery, where he says. Everything. So. Carefully. And. Disjointed--wears on you after a while. And he is given VERY little dialog, I guess to make him some "man of mystery".1 point for the cinematography.

 As to others giving the film a 1/10 - because there isn't a zero - they have been betrayed and striking back.
 There is quite a lot of excellent elements and direction.
 The minimalism is a key factor.

If you do watch, watch as a student of sorts, not as the audience and take from it what you will.

reviews.review_title: Underrated story telling at it's best
reviews.content: Siberia is film making at it's best. I was quite surprised to see this film garnering negative reviews almost across the board. It seems most likely that people went into this film with John Wick on their minds, which I think is unavoidable and automatic. Even I began watching Siberia with thoughts of Wick in the back of my head. It's hard not to. However this is not John Wick or even an action film. The association with the Wick Series is apparent throughout the film. The same sets, clothing, accents, and even the main character's demeanour lends it's self to comparison. I think the association with Wick has doomed Siberia by creating a failure of expectations.Had this film been made in distance from the Wick series, it would be easier for viewers to appreciate the nuances that for me, made this film so powerful. On so many levels this film shined, in character development, in story, or how the film maker took a traditional Hollywood theme and made it their own. And it is on this last point that will make this film in hindsight a great film. It stands out from other films with the same goal in mind, to gain wealth from diamonds by providing a fresh platform that all other films seem to recycle through.The feel of the film seems to mix up past genres in small doses, a bit of Film Noir, old spy films, and Hitchcock. The interlacing of ethics and morals and choices characters are faced with creates high drama at various points through the film, and yet it is all so subtle. Even the apex of the film is hardly recognised due to the seemingly slow pace delivery, and yet watching the character's expression and acting captures the viewer in that moment of anguish and anxiety.The ending sequences are full of promise and that promise remains until the very end. While one's optimism might lead you to think of the old west gunfighter on a dusty street, the arch of the moment steals the viewer's momentum. It doesn't end with a bang as one would expect from characters we are invested in, or the star power of Mr. Reeves, but instead with a whimper. Yet it is realistic to the end.For those willing to look past the John Wick comparison, the viewer is treated to a well honed story that could have easily become convoluted. That the story escaped so many typical tricks and cliches of film making deserves to be applauded. I was left in the end, feeling invested in the two main characters, and empathised with their journey, and also feelings like I have watched something fresh and yet so old and time honoured.

reviews.review_title: a meditation on how quickly things can go wrong
reviews.content: This isn't a balls to the wall action thriller a la John Wick. It's not a steamy romance movie, either. To me, it's a meditation on how quickly things can go wrong. How little of life is in our control, and how sometimes you just are swept up in things without any time to really understand.There are certainly elements of both action and romance, of course. Keanu Reeves plays Lucas, a humble salesman dealing with a particularly large diamond deal. Things go wrong from the very beginning, and we follow Keanu as he searches for a missing business partner who has already set a string of events in motion which were (to me) always inescapable.What feels initially like a straightforward gangster diamond deal flick then takes a sudden turn when Lucas crosses paths with a beautiful bar owner. What is initially a run of the mill episode of a salesman husband cheating on the road turns into something surprising for both viewer and Lucas.After some time exploring this strange and beautiful relationship Lucas has stumbled across we return to the tale of diamonds, and things continue to get worse and worse here. Once again, it seems to me that this is all largely out of Lucas's control. Keanu does an excellent job of portraying someone who is trying hard to make the best of the terrible hand he's been dealt.Eventually, Lucas has to make a tough decision. In some sense, we see Keanu make a much more difficult and masculine decision than he ever did in John Wick. He quietly shoulders all the responsibility for things beyond his control, likely saving the lives of the two women who meant something to him.The important thing to me with this movie is that it's almost completely believable. In real life things are messy, the protagonist isn't always a hero, but he/she probably does mostly try to do right. Most importantly, in real life things don't always end in a satisfying way. Sometimes they just end, and it's up to you to find your own meaning in the randomness of the experience.

reviews.review_title: Something New and out of the ordinary !

"Siberia" is an unconventional take on your basic love affair / story. The film begins one way, and goes in many directions with Reeves and Ularu serving as the grounding factor that makes you want to keep watching. Reeves is his usual minimalistic self, a technique which he owns perfectly. And Ularu gives a stellar performance exercising her brilliant acting chops in all its splendor for all to see! If you want to see something thats not run of the mill, give Siberia a shot. You won't be disappointed ! Director Matthew Ross succeeds in bringing his vision across brilliantly.Check it out !
Sammy Peralta
(Actor, Recording Artist, Producer)

reviews.review_title: Talented Acting, Convoluted Storytelling & Terrible Plot.
reviews.content: Good news and bad news.The good news is Ana Ularu (Katya) absolutely shines as the damsel in distress as the many facets of her character plays off in a subtle and heart-wrenchingly beautiful way through her thoughtful, seductive and adorable acting. She is the very reason I would rate anymore than a single star. I really wish her the best in her career, and hope she continues to blossom.The bad news is a handful. To begin with, Keanu's acting was typical of his stoic, nonchalant, conserved style - yet it becomes deeply problematic in the setting of this film. The decision of casting him as Lucas is puzzling. Lucas (Keanu's character) is a multi-faced, convoluted, at times a victim of cowardice yet simultaneously a courageous man capable of commendable acts of heroism. This requires an extremely subtle, sensuous portrayal that does not fit Keanu's acting profile at all. One could immediately recognize the disparity between personas in the numerous sex scenes between him and Ana - metaphorically, with her presence Keanu almost strikes as an amateur, heedless virgin who is not sure whether he should put his hands on her waist, or on her breasts. Ironically, his character Lucas, is supposed to be a 51 year old, married, shrewd, successful and experienced diamond smuggler. It is just out of proportion. In an attempt to finally mobilize Keanu's talent as an action-thriller superstar, the film ends with its only shootout sequence between him and 4 Russian gangsters who aren't even clothed with body armor. Yet it is of little to no consolation to both Keanu and fans of his work, as regardless of a vaguely pathetic shoot-out near a cabin in the woods (which supposedly serves as the exhilarating coda to all the build-up and suspense), Keanu suffers a tragic death being blasted into oblivion by a smug Russian Pablo-Escobar-lookalike thug shouldering a 12-gauge shotgun. We catch one final camera shot of Keanu's dead lifeless face on the ground, which is followed by somber music and rolling credits. To that I say: What the f.Besides the troubling casting decisions of the film's male protagonist, the larger storytelling and plot is probably even more to blame in terms of its stodgy approach in narrating a potentially intriguing set of events, and the sloppy, contrived design of the larger blueprint. A few examples and comparisons could help clarify this phenomenon.In terms of the uninspired storytelling, one could take the instance in which the story fails to make much sense when Lucas's perfectly harmonious marriage (suggestive of him skype calling his wife back home as he is on business trips), is immediately followed by his seeking out of Katya at 2am in the morning and having "hot-rodeo-sex" right on the couch of the empty bar. Okay, perhaps one could argue it's the duality of man. Sure, then what about the other case that could be made for an earlier sequence, when 2 drunk Russian cretins decide to ambush a tipsy Lucas and as one of them lays a hand on Lucas's shoulder, Lucas responds with disquieting speed as he counters the assailant in the stomach with a well aimed uppercut? So it seems our protagonist clearly is an advanced combatant with a high level of vigilance even when drunk - yet, a sucker punch (which ended the bar-fight sequence) to Lucas's face is supposed to knock him unconscious outside in the snow for ages until the bar closes and our dear Katya discovers his seemingly lifeless body? It just doesn't make sense. The story even teases us with potentials for exciting conflicts between Lucas and rogue special forces (Spetnaz) within his conversation with an associate's brother, yet it all accumulates to nothing but disappointment and a lingering sense of profuse confusion. So perhaps this truly was just supposed to be a softcore-porn/rugged-romance thriller. If so, don't give clues/hints of no avail! If so, don't cast an action star such as Keanu!To further the already illogical storytelling, the plot is its "blood-brother". It seems overtly contrived in moments as various scenic settings are reminiscent of Keanu's iconic "John Wick" style, with lavish, eastern European ecclesiastical architecture and illegal indulgences that insinuate the degenerate socialite lifestyle. Yet on the other hand, another 50% of the film takes place in what one could only describe as a resemblance of "Old McDonald had a farm" except it's in Siberia. It's just as confusing for both the viewer, as it probably was for our poor Keanu who just seems terribly out of place standing in front of Katya's earthly, pastoral wooden house, while he himself sports either a Porsche or Land-rover and expensive clothes... In one moment, Keanu is singing Russian drinking songs with rural locals in the Siberian forest exchanging cheeky Russian aphorisms - the next, he is sitting in a private club of a Russian gangster and coerced into instructing Katya to suck the other mans penis in participation in some grotesque ceremony of brotherly bondage... The list continues since there is just too many totally contradicting elements one could name, and even if this is some sort of artistic literary fusion of juxtaposition, it fails to achieve harmony. Ultimately, despite its best attempts, the film fails miserably in its marriage of its cast and plot, and if anything, it again just leaves the viewer unsatisfied both ways. Neither is the action thriller that never was, nor is the memorable love affair that seemed to never be.(This review has no intention in critiquing the character, aptitude and accomplishment of any of its actors. It is merely a commentary upon the objective work as a whole!)

PUBLIC SERVICE ANNOUNCEMENTWell, there's 104 minutes of my life I'll never get back. One star is generous. Pet Peeve: When movies end abruptly, leave you hanging, with no real "end" to the storyline. It's so frustrating after investing a chunk of time (104 minutes, for example), getting emotionally invested in a movie, waiting for a fabulous ending, all wrapped up in a bow. Then the final credits start rolling up the screen. Really??!!?? That's the end? That's no ending! You've gotta be kidding. This is one of THOSE endings, and my whole purpose of this review.Groan. 
Proceed at your own risk.

reviews.review_title: Siberia is a movie about relationships between people...
reviews.content: First of all, I must sincerely admit that I've been immensely thrilled about this movie since I read its short synopsis and later saw the first picture of Keanu from the set in Winnipeg, Canada, and afterwards, I became even more worked up about the fan updates, photos which many of them graciously shared on their social media. I was following all the news with meticulous attention, very carefully analyzing videos regularly recorded by people equally interested in the film plot and especially one of its cast member, thanks to whom I found out about this indie production. But for him, I'm more than sure that I would have never come across it. When I first saw a trailer, I felt even more curious and eager than before and when so many bad opinions popped up about Siberia, I felt almost obliged to share with you my own insights and impressions. I started watching the movie in the late night and was a bit afraid of what I read in most of the reviews that the movie makes you fall asleep after very first minutes of its length. It is definitely not an action-packed flick with many plot twists incessantly bumping up your emotions. It is not an artistic masterpiece or a typical romance film about two characters ideally tailored to each other. Nonetheless, it is indeed a very engaging, original, intriguing production touching some a bit psychological issues of our lives. I know there are many people, so-called film critics, who consider it as a dull, lacking emotions, action, pace, chemistry between the leading actors, soporific low-budget film. I can't agree with any of these points, I didn't feel sleepy at any time or scene when I was watching it with unchangeably interest, and enthrallment with its very Russian, enchanting music composed by Daniel Bensi and Saunder Jurriaans. I think that the movie gains a lot also thanks to wonderful exterior shots of Saint Petersburg and real Siberian woods. At the beginning of the movie, we're getting to know Keanu's character, Lucas Hill, who is supposed to meet with his working partner Pyotr in a beautiful, yet so mysterious, Russian equivalent of Rome, known from such epic, unforgettable books like "Crime and Punishment", "The Idiot" by Fyodor Dostoevsky (which, by the way, I recommend anyone to read and due to them understand how important for not only the Eastern but worldwide culture this place undoubtedly is). Lucas is a reserved, stoic guy who isn't fulfilled with his current life and uncertain business he became a part of. After landing at the airport, he instantly drives to the hotel where he and Pyotr planned to see. This trip would have been just another ordinary deal for Lucas if only his partner had appeared with diamonds for Mr. Boris Volkov exquisitely played by Russian actor Pasha Lychnikoff ("A Good Day to Die Hard", "Chernobyl Diaries"). "Volkov isn't a good man to disappoint", ensures Lucas when he tries to contact Pyotr who just before Hill's plane has taken off called him being evidently very jovial about the perspective of earning a solid sum of money. Unfortunately, after this scene, nothing seems to fall into place. Lucas patiently tries to look for his apparently carefree colleague in a wilderness of Siberia, in a little village situated in the middle of nowhere, where he falls into a passionate romance with a fearless woman (probably equally fearless in real life) named Katya who, as it later turns out, has a very supportive family consists of thoroughly plainspoken brothers. Their first meeting is very little romantic. Although Katya, a modest café owner, seems to be intrigued by the lonely American straightaway. They differ a lot, they come from completely distinct worlds. Nevertheless, some strange, unexplainable bond connects them and later makes them two partners in crime (here we can notice some Bonnie and Clyde reference to this very unconventional couple). They found each other in difficult, definitely unfavorable circumstances, two lost souls searching for lively feeling, passion, an adventure. I can see in these characters two unsatisfied people with their repetitive lives, grey, bleak reality. Nothing vibrant, invigorating awaited Lucas. Nothing new, unusual Katya anticipated until they coincidentally decide to break the rules, the clichéd convenances which they always have to obey before. They eventually let themselves to explore something deeper, different, in a way releasing themselves from the invisible cages in which they were trapped, cages of their own limitations, faded emotions. When I first found out about Siberia, I didn't expect it to be a tragic love story. Since it is not stereotypical at all, I felt even more absorbed while watching it. I know that there are people, especially these all professional critics, who wanted to see another action, stirring film with Keanu running, shooting, wearing a bloodstained suit. John Wick was some kind of renaissance movie for our man, at least this is what journalists tend to write and, speaking honestly, I can't approve their view. Before John Wick, there were other great productions and I'm now referring to a very underrated samurai story "47 Ronin", a delightful comedy written by Keanu's long-time friend Stephen Hamel (who is, worth-mentioning fact, also an author of the Siberia story) and Keanu's engrossing brainchild called "Man of Tai Chi". Of course, non-fans, film enthusiasts could not know about all these projects, because, in fact, it was "John Wick" who sort of made Keanu recognizable and in the spotlight again among less well-informed folks. I believe that the negative and detractive reviews come generally from the viewers who were ready to watch Keanu beating up bad guys and being a killing machine, a man who terrifies Russians, not is petrified by them like it is in Lucas's case. I don't want to declare that Siberia is what I was hoping for because, as most of you, I really wanted to find out more about Mr. Hill's past, what brought him to become a diamond merchant, what kind of life he normally leads when he's not dealing with any business. The whole story was invented by a man who was involved in creating "Henry's Crime", the film I very much enjoyed and think about it as a very comforting, light comedy with some crime, romantic threads as well. The script was written by an Oscar nominee- Scott B. Smith. I know that some fans might have anticipated something huge, astounding, with a great dose of action scenes. However, I can't stand reading people's comments who can only complain about the supposed lack of emotions, boring editing, too explicit sex scenes (are they really? I'm not a big fan of film romances, but there are other movies with much braver script). Can't they detect how much effort and courage it actually took to make such film? The Mixed-genre movies aren't those which we got used to seeing, at least average viewers, usually films can be classified into one, two specific types. "Siberia" is a unique, exceptional film, kept in a rather indie climate. I like how they pictured Russians, pretty plausibly, and they did a great job casting real eastern actors instead of Americans ineptly attempting to impersonate Russian mentality and pretend their challenging for western performers accent. I think people should appreciate "Siberia" for its non-typical romantic thread, it's after all, in my genuine opinion, the movie about relationships between people- Katya's with her family, Lucas with his wife, Lucas and Katya's relation, Volkov with his "blood-brothers". It's a special film about finding love, not this one which we know from cute, immature Hollywood romantic comedies, in the most inconvenient circumstances, in a cold, frosty world. I can see some Romeo and Juliet reference as well-two seemingly unlike people, Katya's family influence, Russian clan who wants to dictate their female member the best way to settle down and live, and this way is far from she probably dreams of, sudden awaking of strong feelings between two lovers who descend from variant realities. People should appreciate Siberia for its idea of impossible love, for this little, unfortunately less exploited, suspense, action thread, its shooting scene which ends with a very moving, in my opinion, final, spellbinding music and, I wouldn't be myself If I didn't bring this up-Keanu's polished Russian, his distinctive coat and Canadian town Marquette which plays Russian Siberia area very convincingly. I hope sooner or later I'll be able to purchase Siberia on Blu-Ray, because I want to have it in my collection. To be honest, this indie production didn't wholeheartedly impress me, but it certainly engraved in my memory as a good, well-directed, extra-ordinary independent picture.

reviews.review_title: Keanu Reeves being pranked by a Film crew.
reviews.content: If you have ever seen one of those situations where someone famous gets pranked and everyone else apart from them know, then you will get this film. What I imagine is happening is that Reeves has been told they are making a film and he has to stand in at short notice so hasn't had time to read the script first but "don't worry Mr Reeves we will feed you the lines as we film!" Then they put him in the most stupid scenes which is why he spends all the film with a look that says, "is this really going on?". I can imagine the pranksters laughing in a room someone and saying, "make him do this now!".The good bits of this film - the opening titles give you the idea that you are about to watch an exciting thriller or spy movie, they really built up my hopes. They are sadly wasted on this film. Maybe one day someone will make a good thriller movie called Siberia and can reuse them.Then the movie starts and that's where it all goes downhill. Some critics have said that this film goes at a snail's pace, they are wrong, it in fact goes along at the speed of a glacier. I am not sure what sort of boring life you must have to lead if this was a thriller to you, maybe you have been in stasis but awake at the same time for a few decades. You would get more excited watching a four-hour video of two people making flatpack furniture.There is a good reason that all the main characters drink copious amounts of vodka, and I assume that it is real vodka, so that they can get through their scenes.I won't spoil the film about talking about the plod, I mean plot, but I will say that if you gave a young teenage boy the task of imagining how adults get intimate and the kind of things they would do and say at those times it would be at least half of the film.All is not lost though. Should you have someone you want revenge on, invite them over and watch the film together. You will have the pleasure of knowing that inside they are seething with rage at losing some of their precious lifespan.I won't spoil the film about talking about the plod, I mean plot, but I will say that if you gave a teenage boy the task of imagining how adults get intimate and the kind of things they would do and say at those times it would be at least half of the film.

What was missing for me is that moment when one actually cares about at least one of the characters in a film. There's not enough backstory to evoke a connected feeling to the plot drivers: not the small town Russian cafe girl, who invites Reeves' character to have sex for no apparent reason (no chemistry here); not her brother and his bro-gang (too old to be but still high school bully-pranksters); not the brutish, misogynistic gangster or his gold-chained bodyguards; and not the Cheater, the bad boy businessman with a proclivity for guns-and-money criminal activity. And who, in a state of extreme twitterpation, has lost the presence of mind required to realize a booty call to cafe girl has a significantly high probability to segue into scream-till-you-sell-your-soul pain and anguish and possible permanent disfigurement.I had questions. Why did the writer bother to introduce the Reeves' character's wife? Yet fail to do a bit of gemological research for the sake of believe-ability? Why show the collective aptitude of brother's bro-gang in the first cafe scene, then again in the unnecessary and depressing hunting scene?Then I thought--this movie was filmed in Canada (mostly), it cost two million to produce and barely broke half a million at the box office. So perhaps it was (unintentionally) born to be a tax write off for investors?Better luck next time.

meta_summary: When a business deal in Russia goes south, a U.S. diamond merchant (Keanu Reeves) and his lover (Ana Ularu) are caught in a lethal crossfire between the buyer and federal intelligence service.
